docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare is a fiscal time bomb, unsustainable over the long haul and badly in need of major structural changes to save it. That, at least, is what Republicans are arguing as they begin yet another effort to pass Medicare legislation, a central element of President Bush's domestic agenda. The Bush administration has set the bar very high this year, demanding that Congress pass not just a new prescription drug benefit, a feat hard enough, but also sweeping changes in Medicare to get more private health plans involved. The quest for that kind of structural change is fraught with political danger: many Democrats assert that it would amount to privatizing a fundamentally sound and popular program and eventually throwing millions of elderly people onto the mercies of the private insurance industry.

headline.main: Washington Talk; Medicare Caught Up In Politics

docs.abstract: Republican leaders in Bush administration and Congress, despite political risk, are pressing for structural change in Medicare to get more private health plans involved; hold program is fiscal time bomb unsustainable over long haul; Democrats argue relying on competition among private health plans to hold down costs is unlikely to work (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Health Insurance Plan of New York signed a deal on Friday to move its headquarters and 1,600 employees to downtown from Midtown Manhattan, two people involved in the deal said yesterday. In a transaction that real estate experts described as the largest move to downtown from Midtown since the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, 2001, HIP signed a 20-year lease for more than 500,000 square feet of space in the office complex at 55 Water Street, with plans to relocate in the summer of 2004. HIP's offices are now at 7 West 34th Street and 132 West 31st Street.

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the Tedesco family of Bergenfield, N.J., carefree holidays ended five years ago when their daughter Annie, then 15, had a severe reaction after eating shellfish. On their next trip to Florida, said Mike Tedesco, Annie's father, ''we had to keep an eye on her at all times and watch what she ate.'' Even french fries prepared in the same oil used to fry shrimp could have sent Annie into life-threatening anaphylactic shock again. ''One minute she could be fine and the next she could be in respiratory distress.'' To many people, sampling foreign flavors is one of travel's greatest attractions. But six million to seven million Americans are estimated to have serious food allergies, according to the Food Allergy and Anaphylaxis Network, a nonprofit advocacy group in Fairfax, Va., and for them travel can be a minefield. As I know from traveling with my husband, Andrew, who is allergic to peanuts, the usual concerns about restaurant and airline meals are compounded by language and cultural differences.
docs.abstract: Susan Catto Practical Traveler column offers advice on coping with food allergies while traveling; drawing (M)

headline.main: His Art Hangs, and Trespasses, in the Most Notable Places

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Flo Wiener had her second child 12 years ago, she was ready for a break from practicing law. She quit her job at the New York State Attorney General's office and chose, as she puts it, to ''do the June Cleaver thing.'' She stayed home for nine years, but as her children grew older, she began contemplating a return to the work force. ''I had been seriously considering going back to work for a year,'' said Ms. Wiener, who lives in Edgemont. ''One opportunity had come up but it wasn't right because it didn't fit with my public sector background.''
docs.abstract: Article on women in Westchester County, NY, who left their professional jobs to raise families and are now returning to work force; key is to view old jobs and time spent at home as integrated rather than isolated experiences; biggest impediment to returning to work is figuring out what to do; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Never mind how they found the money, but the Republicans who had a grip on Trenton until 15 months ago dispensed breaks up and down the income ladder. For the affluent, Gov. Christie Whitman cut the top income tax rate, to 6.37 percent from 7 percent. For the full spectrum of taxpayers she inaugurated property tax relief in the form of annual rebate checks. The near-poor got subsidized health insurance, and Medicaid recipients, the poor and disabled, received expanded services like dental and chiropractic care. All of these items are now on the table, as people in the State House say, since it has become stunningly obvious that the state's largesse must be pared back. The struggle over Gov. McGreevey's proposed budget will decide whose breaks will be canceled.

headline.main: The Poor Get Poorer In McGreevey's Budget

docs.abstract: Laura Mansnerus On Politics column assesses which groups of taxpayers are most likely to see their tax breaks stripped away as New Jersey Assembly and Senate budget committees scrutinize Gov McGreevey's proposed budget (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With both sides reporting scant progress in negotiations, the union representing 28,000 apartment building workers and the association representing building owners say that they remain far apart on critical issues and that there is a strong chance of a strike when the current contract expires at 12:01 a.m. on April 21. Worried about a possible walkout, the Realty Advisory Board, the group representing building owners and managers, has sent manuals to 3,000 unionized buildings with one million residents, advising them to make preparations for a strike by doormen, janitors, superintendents, elevator operators and other building workers.

headline.main: As Labor Talks Bog Down, Tenants Face Prospect of Holding Doors and Hauling Trash

docs.lead_paragraph: United Airlines said yesterday that its pilots had ratified labor concessions that would save it $1.1 billion a year and that it had reached tentative agreement with its mechanics on cost cuts. The airline said one of its smaller unions, representing flight dispatchers, had also voted in favor of concessions.
docs.abstract: United Airlines says its pilots have ratified labor concessions that would save it $1.1 billion a year; reaches tentative accord with mechanics on wage cuts and other moves to save $349 million a year over six years; flight dispatchers also approve concessions; UAL Corp chief executive Glenn F Tilton says United needs moves to emerge from bankruptcy and succeed for long term; seeks $2.56 billion a year in labor concessions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is quietly considering alternatives to his commuter tax proposal. Some are being contemplated by Democrats in the State Assembly, and some could include a tax increase for New York City residents as well as commuters. Officially, Mr. Bloomberg stands by his original commuter tax proposal; he will present it next week as part of his executive budget. That plan calls for up to a 2.7 percent tax on suburban commuters, as well as an income tax cut for New York City residents. It has been broadly rejected by Republican legislators and Gov. George E. Pataki, who reiterated yesterday at a news conference that the commuter tax ''would have a horrible effect on jobs.''

headline.main: Mayor Ponders Commuter Tax With a Twist
